name: Flat Barbell Bench Press
description: The gold standard compound chest exercise performed lying flat on a bench while pressing a barbell from chest level to full arm extension. This foundational movement builds overall chest mass, strength, and pressing power while engaging multiple upper body muscle groups.
instructions: Lie flat on a bench with feet firmly planted on the floor and shoulder blades retracted and depressed
Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width with wrists stacked over elbows
Unrack the bar and position it directly over your shoulders with arms fully extended
Lower the bar in a controlled manner to your mid-chest, touching lightly at the sternum
Press the bar back up explosively while maintaining tight core and leg drive, fully extending arms without locking elbows
formCues: Keep shoulder blades pinched together throughout
Maintain natural arch in lower back
Drive feet into floor for leg drive
Bar path should travel slightly back toward face on press
Keep wrists neutral and stacked over elbows
commonMistakes: Not using full range of motion

name: Incline Barbell Bench Press 30-Degree
description: A variation of the bench press performed on a 30-degree incline bench targeting the upper chest fibers more intensely. This moderate incline angle provides an optimal balance between upper chest activation and overall pressing strength.
instructions: Set the bench to a 30-degree incline and position yourself with feet flat on the floor
Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width and unrack with arms extended
Retract shoulder blades and create a slight arch in the upper back
Lower the bar to your upper chest just below the collarbone in a controlled manner
Press the bar back up to the starting position while keeping constant tension on the upper chest
formCues: Keep chest high and proud throughout the movement
Lower bar to upper chest, not neck
Maintain 45-degree elbow angle relative to torso
Press in a slight arc back toward face
commonMistakes: Lowering bar too high toward neck

name: Incline Barbell Bench Press 45-Degree
description: A steeper incline press variation that maximally targets the clavicular head of the pectoralis major while increasing anterior deltoid involvement. This angle creates greater shoulder flexion demands and is excellent for developing upper chest definition.
instructions: Set bench to 45-degree angle and sit with back firmly against pad
Grip barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width and unrack with straight arms
Brace core and maintain shoulder blade retraction throughout
Lower bar under control to upper chest just below clavicle
Drive bar up and slightly back, fully extending arms while keeping shoulders down
formCues: Do not let bar drift forward
Focus on squeezing upper chest at top
commonMistakes: Converting to shoulder press by going too steep
Grip too wide causing shoulder stress

name: Decline Barbell Bench Press
description: A bench press variation performed on a decline bench targeting the lower chest fibers and sternal head of the pectoralis major. The declined angle reduces shoulder stress while allowing for heavier loads due to the shortened range of motion.
instructions: Secure feet under the leg pads of a decline bench set to 15-30 degrees
Grip barbell at shoulder width or slightly wider and unrack with arms extended
Keep shoulder blades retracted and core braced throughout
Lower bar to lower chest just below nipple line
Press bar up and slightly back toward face until arms are fully extended
formCues: Keep lower back in contact with bench
Press in an arc back toward rack
commonMistakes: Setting decline too steep causing blood rush to head

name: Close-Grip Barbell Bench Press
description: A bench press variation with hands placed shoulder-width apart or narrower, shifting emphasis to the triceps while still heavily engaging the inner chest. This exercise is excellent for building tricep strength and lockout power in pressing movements.
instructions: Lie on flat bench with feet planted and grip barbell at shoulder width or slightly narrower
Unrack the bar with arms fully extended directly over shoulders
Keep elbows tucked close to body at approximately 30-45 degrees
Lower bar under control to mid-chest while maintaining elbow tuck
Press bar straight up powerfully, focusing on tricep engagement at lockout
formCues: Grip should not be so narrow it strains wrists
Touch bar to lower chest, not upper
commonMistakes: Grip too narrow causing wrist pain
Touching bar too high on chest
Using excessive weight with poor form

name: Wide-Grip Barbell Bench Press
description: A bench press variation with hands placed wider than standard grip to maximize pectoralis major stretch and activation while reducing tricep involvement. This grip emphasizes the outer chest fibers but requires good shoulder mobility.
instructions: Lie on flat bench and grip barbell 1.5 to 2 times shoulder width apart
Unrack bar with arms extended, positioning it over lower chest
Retract shoulder blades firmly and maintain throughout
Lower bar in controlled manner to mid-chest, allowing elbows to flare to about 75 degrees
Press bar up while focusing on chest squeeze, avoiding excessive lockout
formCues: Ensure adequate shoulder mobility before attempting
Do not let bar bounce at bottom
Stop short of full lockout to maintain tension
Keep wrists as straight as possible
commonMistakes: Grip too wide causing shoulder impingement

name: Barbell Floor Press
description: A partial range bench press performed lying on the floor, eliminating leg drive and limiting the range of motion to focus on lockout strength and tricep power. Excellent for lifters with shoulder issues as it reduces shoulder strain at the bottom position.
instructions: Lie flat on floor with knees bent and feet flat, position under loaded barbell in rack
Grip bar slightly wider than shoulder width and unrack
Lower bar under control until upper arms rest on floor briefly
Pause momentarily with triceps on floor without relaxing
Press bar back up explosively, fully extending arms
formCues: Let arms come to complete stop on floor
Keep glutes and upper back pressed into floor

name: Paused Barbell Bench Press
description: An advanced bench press variation requiring a deliberate pause at the chest before pressing, eliminating the stretch reflex and requiring pure concentric strength. This powerlifting staple builds explosive power and addresses sticking points in the lift.
instructions: Set up as for standard bench press with tight arch and retracted shoulder blades
Unrack bar and position over chest with arms extended
Lower bar under control to mid-chest, touching lightly
Hold bar motionless on chest for 1-3 seconds while maintaining tightness
Explode bar off chest on command or after pause, pressing to full lockout
formCues: Maintain full body tension during pause
Do not sink or bounce bar on chest
Keep elbows in consistent position during pause
Breathe in before descent, hold during pause
Explode with full force after pause

name: Flat Dumbbell Press
description: A versatile pressing movement using dumbbells that allows for greater range of motion and independent arm training compared to barbell variations. The unstable nature of dumbbells recruits more stabilizer muscles and helps correct strength imbalances.
instructions: Sit on flat bench with dumbbells on thighs, kick them up as you lie back
Position dumbbells at chest level with palms facing forward, feet flat on floor
Press dumbbells up and slightly inward until arms are extended with slight bend
Lower dumbbells in a wide arc until you feel a stretch in the chest
Press back up bringing dumbbells together at the top without clanking
formCues: Keep dumbbells in line with mid-chest
Maintain slight arch in lower back
Control the descent, do not drop
Full stretch at bottom, squeeze at top
commonMistakes: Letting dumbbells drift too far down toward stomach

name: Incline Dumbbell Press
description: An upper chest focused pressing movement performed on an inclined bench with dumbbells. Combines the benefits of incline pressing for upper pec development with the range of motion and stabilization benefits of dumbbells.
instructions: Set bench to 30-45 degree incline and sit back with dumbbells at shoulder level
Position dumbbells with palms facing forward, elbows at 45 degrees to torso
Press dumbbells up and together in an arc until arms are extended
Lower under control allowing a full stretch in the upper chest
Maintain constant tension throughout the movement
formCues: Keep head and upper back against bench
Lower dumbbells to outer edge of upper chest
Focus on upper chest contraction at top
commonMistakes: Bench angle too steep becoming shoulder press

name: Decline Dumbbell Press
description: A lower chest targeting press performed on a decline bench with dumbbells. The declined position emphasizes the sternal head of the pectoralis major while the dumbbells allow for natural arm path and increased range of motion.
instructions: Secure legs under pads of decline bench and lie back with dumbbells at chest
Position dumbbells at sides of lower chest with palms facing forward
Press dumbbells up and slightly together until arms are extended
Lower under control to starting position with deep stretch
Maintain constant tension throughout without locking elbows
formCues: Keep lower back pressed against bench
Do not hold breath too long

name: Flat Dumbbell Fly
description: An isolation movement that stretches and contracts the chest through a wide arcing motion. This exercise maximizes pectoral stretch under load and is excellent for developing chest width and the mind-muscle connection.
instructions: Lie on flat bench with dumbbells extended above chest, palms facing each other
Maintain a slight bend in elbows locked at 15-20 degrees throughout
Lower dumbbells out to sides in wide arc until chest is fully stretched
Feel deep stretch at bottom without going past shoulder plane
Squeeze chest to bring dumbbells back up in hugging motion
commonMistakes: Bending elbows too much turning into press

name: Incline Dumbbell Fly
description: An isolation movement performed on an incline bench to target the clavicular head of the pectoralis major. The inclined position stretches the upper chest fibers while providing excellent muscle fiber recruitment for upper chest development.
instructions: Set bench to 30-45 degree incline and lie back with dumbbells above chest
Start with arms extended, palms facing each other, slight elbow bend
Lower dumbbells in wide arc to sides until upper chest is stretched
Maintain fixed elbow angle throughout the movement
Contract upper chest to bring dumbbells back together overhead
formCues: Lower until you feel stretch, not pain
commonMistakes: Bench too steep reducing chest activation

name: Decline Dumbbell Fly
description: An isolation movement performed on a decline bench targeting the lower and outer chest fibers. The declined angle provides a unique stretch and contraction pattern that emphasizes the sternal head of the pectoralis major.
instructions: Secure feet under pads of decline bench and lie back with dumbbells above chest
Start with arms extended, palms facing each other, slight elbow bend
Lower dumbbells out to sides in arc until chest is fully stretched
Maintain the same elbow angle throughout descent and ascent
Squeeze lower chest to bring dumbbells back to starting position

name: Dumbbell Squeeze Press
description: A chest pressing variation where dumbbells are pressed together throughout the movement, creating constant isometric tension in the chest. This exercise maximizes inner chest activation and enhances the mind-muscle connection.
instructions: Lie on flat bench with dumbbells held together above chest, palms facing each other
Press dumbbells firmly together with maximum force throughout
Lower both dumbbells to chest while maintaining squeeze pressure
Touch dumbbells to mid-chest while still pressing together
Press back up while continuously squeezing dumbbells against each other
formCues: Press dumbbells together as hard as possible
Use moderate weight for best activation

name: Dumbbell Pullover
description: A unique exercise that stretches the chest and lats through shoulder extension while lying perpendicular across a bench. This movement expands the rib cage and targets both chest and back muscles simultaneously.
instructions: Lie perpendicular across bench with only upper back supported, feet flat on floor
Hold one dumbbell with both hands extended above chest, palms supporting inner plate
Lower dumbbell in arc behind head while keeping slight bend in elbows
Stretch chest and lats at bottom position without overextending shoulders
Pull dumbbell back up to starting position using chest and lat contraction
formCues: Keep hips slightly below bench level
Feel stretch in chest and lats

name: Single-Arm Dumbbell Press
description: A unilateral pressing movement that challenges core stability while addressing strength imbalances between sides. Pressing with one arm at a time increases anti-rotation demands and allows for greater focus on each pectoral.
instructions: Lie on flat bench with one dumbbell at chest level, other arm extended for balance
Plant feet firmly and brace core to prevent rotation
Press dumbbell straight up while resisting body rotation
Lower under control to chest level while maintaining stability
Complete all reps on one side before switching
formCues: Grip bench edge with free hand if needed

name: Neutral-Grip Dumbbell Press
description: A pressing variation with palms facing each other throughout the movement, reducing shoulder stress while maintaining chest activation. This grip is ideal for those with shoulder issues and increases tricep recruitment.
instructions: Lie on flat bench with dumbbells at chest level, palms facing each other
Position elbows close to body at about 45 degrees
Press dumbbells up keeping neutral grip throughout
Bring dumbbells together at top without rotating
Lower under control maintaining neutral wrist position
formCues: Keep palms facing each other always
Elbows tucked closer than standard press
commonMistakes: Not using full range of motion
Going too light due to unfamiliarity

name: Standard Push-Up
description: The fundamental bodyweight pressing movement that builds chest, tricep, and shoulder strength while engaging the entire core. This versatile exercise requires no equipment and can be progressed or regressed easily.
instructions: Start in plank position with hands slightly wider than shoulder-width
Keep body in straight line from head to heels, core braced
Lower chest toward floor by bending elbows to about 90 degrees
Keep elbows at 45-degree angle to body, not flared out
Press back up to starting position while maintaining rigid body line

name: Wide Push-Up
description: A push-up variation with hands placed wider than shoulder-width to emphasize chest stretch and activation while reducing tricep involvement. The wider position increases the difficulty of the movement and places greater demand on the pectorals.
instructions: Start in plank position with hands placed 1.5 times shoulder width apart
Keep fingers pointing slightly outward for wrist comfort
Maintain straight body line from head to heels
Lower chest toward floor allowing elbows to flare more than standard push-up
Press back up focusing on chest contraction
formCues: Allow elbows to flare to about 60-75 degrees
Feel stretch in chest at bottom
commonMistakes: Hands too wide causing shoulder strain
Not reaching full range of motion
Wrist discomfort from poor hand angle

name: Diamond Push-Up
description: An advanced push-up variation with hands close together forming a diamond shape, significantly increasing tricep activation while still engaging the inner chest. This challenging movement builds pressing strength and tricep development.
instructions: Start in plank position with hands together directly under chest
Form diamond shape with index fingers and thumbs touching
Keep elbows close to body as you lower chest toward hands
Lower until chest nearly touches hands while maintaining body alignment
Press back up focusing on tricep and inner chest contraction

name: Incline Push-Up
description: A beginner-friendly push-up regression with hands elevated on a surface, reducing the percentage of body weight being pressed. This exercise is perfect for building initial pushing strength or as part of a warm-up routine.
instructions: Place hands on elevated surface like bench, box, or wall at shoulder width
Walk feet back until body forms straight line at an incline
Brace core and keep body rigid throughout
Lower chest toward elevated surface by bending elbows
Press back up to starting position maintaining body alignment
formCues: Progress to lower surfaces over time

name: Decline Push-Up
description: An advanced push-up variation with feet elevated, increasing the percentage of body weight pressed and shifting emphasis to the upper chest and front deltoids. This progression builds toward more challenging push-up variations.
instructions: Place feet on elevated surface like bench, box, or step
Position hands on floor slightly wider than shoulder width
Create straight line from feet to head with core braced
Lower chest toward floor keeping elbows at 45 degrees
Press back up focusing on upper chest contraction
commonMistakes: Not reaching full range of motion

name: Archer Push-Up
description: A challenging unilateral push-up variation where one arm does most of the work while the other extends to the side for support. This exercise bridges the gap between standard push-ups and one-arm push-ups while building asymmetric strength.
instructions: Start in wide push-up position with arms extended about 1.5x shoulder width
Shift weight toward one arm as you bend that elbow
Keep the other arm straight sliding along the floor for support
Lower chest toward the working hand side
Press back up while shifting weight back to center, alternate sides

name: Pseudo Planche Push-Up
description: An advanced calisthenics movement with hands positioned near the hips and turned outward, creating extreme shoulder and chest demand. This exercise builds toward the planche while developing incredible pushing strength and body control.
instructions: Start in push-up position but with hands placed back near waist/hip level
Turn hands out to the sides or slightly back for wrist comfort
Lean forward significantly so shoulders are well ahead of hands
Lower chest toward floor maintaining forward lean
Press back up keeping weight shifted forward throughout
formCues: Lean as far forward as controllable
commonMistakes: Hands too far forward negating effect

name: Explosive Push-Up
description: A plyometric push-up variation where you press explosively enough to lift hands off the ground, developing power, fast-twitch muscle fiber recruitment, and athletic pressing ability. Can progress to clap push-ups for added challenge.
instructions: Start in standard push-up position with tight core
Lower chest toward floor under control
Explode upward as powerfully as possible pressing through palms
Allow hands to leave the ground at top of movement
Land softly with slight elbow bend and immediately descend into next rep
formCues: Full range of motion on descent

name: Push-Up with Rotation
description: A dynamic push-up variation combining horizontal pressing with rotational core work. At the top of each rep, rotate into a side plank position, engaging obliques and challenging shoulder stability while building functional pressing strength.
instructions: Start in standard push-up position with feet slightly wider for stability
Perform a push-up lowering chest toward floor
As you press up, rotate body and lift one arm toward ceiling
Open into side plank position with arm extended overhead
Return hand to floor and repeat on opposite side
formCues: Rotate from hips, not just shoulders
Keep supporting arm straight in rotation
Stack feet or stagger for stability
commonMistakes: Not fully opening into side plank

name: Pike Push-Up to Chest
description: A hybrid movement combining pike push-up mechanics with a forward diving motion targeting both shoulders and upper chest. This exercise builds overhead pressing strength while incorporating horizontal pushing for comprehensive upper body development.
instructions: Start in pike position with hips high, hands shoulder width on floor
Begin by bending elbows and diving head forward and down toward floor
Continue until chest nearly touches floor between hands
Push back up and rearward returning to pike position
Maintain fluid motion between pike and push-up phases
formCues: Keep hips high in starting position
commonMistakes: Not piking high enough at start

name: High Cable Fly
description: A cable fly variation with pulleys set at the highest position, targeting the lower chest fibers as the arms arc downward. The constant cable tension throughout the movement provides superior muscle engagement compared to free weight alternatives.
instructions: Set cable pulleys to highest position and attach single handles
Grasp handles and step forward into staggered stance for stability
Start with arms extended out to sides and slightly above shoulder height
Bring handles together in arc motion at lower chest or navel level
Squeeze chest at contraction point, then return under control to start
formCues: Keep slight bend in elbows fixed

name: Mid Cable Fly
description: A cable fly performed with pulleys at shoulder height, targeting the mid-chest fibers with constant tension throughout the full range of motion. This is the most balanced cable fly position for overall chest development.
instructions: Set cable pulleys to shoulder height on both sides
Grasp handles and step forward with slight forward lean
Start with arms extended to sides at shoulder height with slight elbow bend
Bring handles together in hugging motion at chest level
Hold peak contraction briefly then return to stretch position under control
commonMistakes: Straightening arms making it a press
Standing too far back losing tension

name: Low Cable Fly
description: A cable fly variation with pulleys set at the lowest position, targeting the upper chest as arms arc upward. This angle mimics the incline fly movement pattern while providing constant cable tension throughout the range of motion.
instructions: Set cable pulleys to lowest position on both sides
Grasp handles and step forward into stable stance
Start with arms down and slightly behind body line
Bring handles up and together in arc finishing at upper chest height
Squeeze upper chest at top, lower under control to start
formCues: Arc hands up toward chin level
commonMistakes: Finishing too low missing upper chest

name: Machine Chest Press
description: A guided pressing movement performed on a chest press machine, providing a safe and stable environment to build pressing strength. Ideal for beginners learning movement patterns or advanced lifters isolating chest with heavy loads to failure.
instructions: Adjust seat height so handles align with mid-chest level
Sit with back flat against pad and feet firmly on floor
Grasp handles with overhand grip at chest level
Press handles forward until arms are extended without locking elbows
Return to start position with control, feeling stretch in chest
formCues: Adjust seat for proper handle alignment

name: Pec Deck Fly
description: A machine-based chest isolation exercise that provides constant tension through a fixed arc of motion. The pec deck eliminates balance requirements, allowing complete focus on chest contraction and excellent mind-muscle connection.
instructions: Adjust seat height so handles align with mid-chest and shoulders
Sit with back flat against pad, place forearms against padded levers
Start with arms open, feeling stretch in chest
Bring pads together in front of chest using chest strength
Squeeze chest hard at contraction, return slowly to start
commonMistakes: Not using full range of motion
Using arm strength instead of chest

name: Banded Push-Up
description: A push-up variation with a resistance band looped around the back and held in the hands, adding accommodating resistance that increases at the top of the movement. This creates greater muscle tension at lockout while maintaining the bodyweight nature of the exercise.
instructions: Loop resistance band across upper back and hold ends in each hand
Assume push-up position with band secured under palms
Perform push-up lowering chest to floor as normal
Press up against increasing band resistance
Fully extend arms feeling maximum tension at top
formCues: Band should be flat across back
commonMistakes: Band too heavy causing form breakdown
Band positioned too high on back

name: Band Chest Press
description: A standing or seated pressing movement using resistance bands anchored behind the body, providing accommodating resistance ideal for home workouts or rehabilitation. The band creates increasing tension through the pressing motion, challenging the chest throughout the range.
instructions: Anchor band at chest height behind you or loop around stable object
Hold band handles or ends at chest level with elbows back
Stand in staggered stance facing away from anchor
Press hands forward and together until arms are extended
Control the return as band pulls arms back to start
commonMistakes: Band anchor too low or high
